gen.metadata.authors: Mahmoud Rajab; Fatma M. El-Hefnawi; Salwa H. Elramly; Marwa H.Bannis
gen.metadata.title: UWB with Gain Enhancement Archimedean Spiral Microstrip Antennas for On-board Satellite Communications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and evaluate Archimedean spiral microstrip antennas with gain enhancement techniques for ultra-wide band satellite communications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Design a monopole Archimedean spiral microstrip antenna (MASMA) with and without stacked substrate (p. 1); Design a dipole Archimedean spiral microstrip antenna (DASMA) with and without stacked substrate (p. 1); Design a 2x2 array of DASMA with and without stacked substrate (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Conduct experimental validation of the simulation results (p. 2)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use stacked substrate techniques to enhance the performance of spiral microstrip antennas in satellite communications (p. 2)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Traditional spiral antennas for satellite communications have limitations such as reduced gain, radiated power, and increased volume when using absorbing materials (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can the gain and bandwidth of spiral microstrip antennas be enhanced for on-board satellite communications? (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.bandwidth: 6.8 to 24 GHz (MASMA without stacked substrate), 6 to 61 GHz (MASMA with stacked substrate), 7.5 to 24 GHz (DASMA without stacked substrate), 7.5 to 15 GHz (DASMA with stacked substrate), 7.5 to 25 GHz (2x2 array DASMA without stacked substrate), 5.8 to 16 GHz (2x2 array DASMA with stacked substrate) (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The stacked substrate technique significantly enhances the gain and bandwidth of all antenna designs (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.gain: 8 dB increase for MASMA, 10 dB increase for DASMA, 12 dB increase for 2x2 array DASMA (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: FR-4 substrate (εr=4.7, h=0.75mm) and RT 5880 (εr=2.2, h=0.508mm) (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Strip line printed on the substrate surface with a width equal to the spiral arm width (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.frequency_b: 6.8 to 24 GHz (MASMA without stacked substrate), 6 to 61 GHz (MASMA with stacked substrate), 7.5 to 24 GHz (DASMA without stacked substrate), 7.5 to 15 GHz (DASMA with stacked substrate), 7.5 to 25 GHz (2x2 array DASMA without stacked substrate), 5.8 to 16 GHz (2x2 array DASMA with stacked substrate) (p. 2)

gen.metadata.authors: Saeidi, T.; S.K.; Not mentioned; Karamzadeh, S.; S.S.; Saleh, S.; T.S.
gen.metadata.title: Miniaturized and Circularly Polarized Dual-Port Metasurface-Based Leaky-Wave MIMO Antenna for CubeSat Communications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To propose a miniaturized MTS-based leaky-wave MIMO antenna optimized for CubeSat communication systems across microwave and millimeter-wave bands (p. 6)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Operate in three bands (3.75–5.25 GHz, 6.4–15.4 GHz, and 22.5–30 GHz) (p. 1); Support frequency- or phase-dependent beamsteering without mechanical parts (p. 1); Achieve a gain of 12.5 dBi and a radiation efficiency of 85% (p. 1); Achieve high gain, radiation efficiency, and circular polarization (p. 6); Evaluate performance metrics such as gain, bandwidth, and return loss (p. 20); Not mentioned; Support high data rates and beamsteering abilities without electrical or mechanical sophistication (p. 6); Ensure reliable long-distance communication with low power consumption (p. 1); Ensure stable circular polarization (p. 20); Design a compact, dual-port MIMO antenna using a modified phased MTS with coffee bean-shaped arrays (p. 6); Achieve high gain and efficiency (p. 20)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the use of the proposed antenna in multi-satellite networks (p. 11); Investigate the thermal and radiation resilience of the antenna materials (p. 21); Explore the integration of the antenna with other space-constrained platforms such as UAVs and terrestrial IoT systems (p. 21); Study the nonlinear performance and dielectric breakdown behavior for higher power applications (p. 21); Investigate the long-term performance and reliability of the antenna in space conditions (p. 1); Not mentioned; Explore the integration of the antenna with other CubeSat components (p. 1); Explore the impact of different MTS configurations on antenna performance (p. 11)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the antenna into CubeSat communication systems for enhanced performance (p. 1); Integrate the proposed antenna design into CubeSat communication systems (p. 6); Integrate the antenna with onboard energy-harvesting systems or intelligent beam-forming ICs (p. 21); Conduct practical tests to validate simulation results (p. 1); Not mentioned; Conduct experimental validation to confirm simulation results (p. 11); Explore the potential for incorporating this antenna into next-generation CubeSat missions (p. 21)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: CubeSats require lightweight, compact, high-performance antennas that meet strict size, weight, and power (SWaP) constraints while sustaining solid performance in severe space conditions (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a miniaturized MTS-based leaky-wave MIMO antenna be designed for CubeSat communication systems? (p. 6); What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna in CubeSat applications? (p. 20); Not mentioned; How can a metasurface-based leaky-wave MIMO antenna be designed to meet CubeSat communication requirements? (p. 1); What are the performance metrics and benefits of the proposed antenna design? (p. 6); What are the key performance metrics and design features that enhance the antenna's efficiency and reliability? (p. 1); How can a miniaturized antenna achieve high gain and efficiency while maintaining stable circular polarization? (p. 20)
esp.domain_methodology.performance_metri: ['Gain', 'Bandwidth', 'Return Loss', 'VSWR', 'Radiation Pattern', 'Radiation Efficiency', 'Axial Ratio', 'Sidelobe Level'] (p. 14, p. 18)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Full-wave simulation using CST Microwave Studio (or HFSS) (p. 18)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms previous studies in terms of compactness, frequency coverage, gain, and multifunctionality (p. 18)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Bidirectional at lower bands and more directional at higher bands (p. 16)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: Fits within the standard 10 × 10 × 10 cm³ CubeSat unit (p. 6)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Miniaturized circular polarized dual-port MTS-based leaky-wave MIMO antenna (p. 20)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT 5880 (εr = 2.1, tan δ = 0.001, h = 1.5 mm) (p. 11)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Rectangular patch connected to a transmission line (p. 7)

gen.metadata.authors: Wenquan Che; Yang Yang; Quan Xue; Siyu Li; Not mentioned; Shaowei Liao
gen.metadata.title: Low-Profile Circularly-Polarized Isoflux Beam Antenna Array Based on Annular Aperture Elements for CubeSat Earth Coverage Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and demonstrate a low-profile 5 GHz sequential rotation-fed antenna array with isoflux radiation pattern for CubeSat earth coverage applications (p. 10)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a low profile and light weight design (p. 10); Optimize the radiator and feeding network parameters to achieve the desired performance (p. 6); Deduce an overall reflection coefficient to characterize impedance matching (p. 2); Design and fabricate a prototype operating at C band (5 GHz) (p. 1); Develop a radiation pattern modelling method for the array (p. 2); Not mentioned; Meet the frequency, footprint size, profile, polarization, AR, gain, and efficiency requirements (p. 6); Ensure good electrical performance (p. 10); Compare performance with existing designs (p. 10)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Not mentioned; Investigate the impact of different substrate materials and thicknesses (p. 7); Explore the use of the antenna array in different CubeSat missions (p. 7); Explore the application of the design method to other frequency bands (p. 10)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; Use the proposed design for CubeSat earth coverage applications (p. 10); Further optimization of the feeding network to improve performance (p. 7)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Small satellites, particularly CubeSats, require antennas with stringent indicators such as low mass, low profile, small size, and mechanical robustness. Current antenna designs for earth coverage beams are often bulky and heavy, limiting their application in CubeSats (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a low-profile antenna array be designed for CubeSat applications? (p. 10); How can the antenna array meet the requirements for a 400 km-orbit CubeSat with a circular earth coverage area of 250 km²? (p. 6); What are the optimal parameters for achieving the required radiation pattern and performance metrics? (p. 6); How can a low-profile, light-weight, and easy-to-integrate antenna array be designed for CubeSat earth coverage applications? (p. 1); Not mentioned; What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna array compared to existing designs? (p. 10)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: R&S ZVA67 VNA and MVG Starlab antenna pattern measurement system (p. 8)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Radiation pattern modelling method, overall reflection coefficient, hybrid synthesis program (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The proposed array features a low profile, light weight, and ease-of-integration, making it suitable for CubeSat applications (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.gain: 4.7 dBic at θ = ±35°, 2.2 dBic at θ = 0° (p. 6)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: CP isoflux beam antenna array based on sequential rotation-fed annular aperture elements (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Two annular apertures: inner aperture (circular patch antenna element) and outer aperture (eight rationally arranged PIFA elements) (p. 10)
